Award.AwardTitle: MIND Alliance for Minority Students with Disabilities in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The MIND Alliance for Minority Students with Disabilities in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics is designed to bring together the expertise and resources of two minority-serving institutions of higher education, Hunter College, City University of New York in New York City, NY and Southern University in Baton Rouge, LA, to increase the quantity and quality of students with disabilities receiving community college and baccalaureate degrees in STEM disciplines and entering the STEM workforce or graduate education. The MIND Alliance is addressing the following objectives:

(1) To successfully retain, graduate and transition secondary school students with disabilities for entry into community college and baccalaureate STEM degree programs.
(2) To successfully retain, graduate and transition students with disabilities from community college degree programs to STEM baccalaureate programs or the workforce.
(3) To successfully retain, graduate and transition students with disabilities from STEM baccalaureate degrees to STEM graduate degrees or the workforce.

Student interventions, which emphasize culturally sensitive student experiences and a career assessment and counseling approach, are combined with traditional promising practices: Summer Institute Programs; Tutoring, Mentoring and Role Modeling; High School Counselor and Teacher Workshops; Research Opportunities and Internship Programs; Student Scholarships and an Annual Science Conference.

The project is being evaluated by a Dr. Allen Lewis, an Associate Professor of Rehabilitation Counseling at Virginia Commonwealth University. Dissemination will focus on the use of web-based diffusion with an emphasis on sharing the partnering model and culturally sensitive career planning approach with a national post-secondary audience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The underrepresentation of women, minority, and people with disabilities in STEM is well documented. The problem becomes even more profound when considered together with the intersectionality effect of race/ethnicity and disability. The MIND Alliance brought together expertise, experience, and considerable institutional, programmatic, and personnel resources of two minority institutions of higher education Hunter College-CUNY and Southern University, Baton Rouge. They provided best practices educational and career development services to students with disabilities from racial and ethnic minority backgrounds to enhance their chance for success in STEM education and careers, and to develop and validate innovative ways to effectively identify such students with science interests, to develop those interests and abilities, and to support these students in their STEM educational and career pursuits. The three broad goals of the MIND Alliance were to: (a) develop high school partnerships with public schools, and with community colleges and universities in New York City, Newark, and Baton Rouge in order to provide motivational enhancement and academic support services to minority students with disabilities. Partnership activities included career assessment and counseling, summer/fall institutes, training workshops for teachers and school counselors in high schools, counselors in the student with disabilities service offices in community colleges and universities, workshops for parents, mentorship for students, and STEM internships and research opportunities for minority students with disabilities; (b) develop a website with career materials to be used by parents, teachers, and school counselors to motivate high school students with disabilities to pursue academic training and careers in STEM; and (c) disseminate evidence-based capacity-building strategies through peer reviewed journals and presentations at National conferences to other entities engaged in improving STEM-related educational and employment opportunities for people with disabilities from minority backgrounds.

Intellectual Merit

A culturally inclusive and disability-sensitive framework for organizing career development concepts and interventions for minority students with disabilities was used to guide the design, implementation, and evaluation of the efficacy of MIND Alliance STEM capacity-building strategies and services. The project was structured to include a strong research and program evaluation group to ensure that every project would have an appropriate research design, sound measurements to operationalize research constructs, optimal data collection strategies, and appropriate statistical techniques for analyzing the outcome data. This approach allowed us to integrate theory with research and practice. The focus on career assessment and planning and the research on motivational enhancement ingredients were unique aspects of this project. We published six peer-reviewed journal articles validating the social-cognitive career theory (SCCT) framework used to inform STEM career development intervention and services.  The MIND Alliance website www.mystem.org, visited by 4000 viewers, contains information about career exploration for students, parents and teachers. A documentary film, the Forerunners, was created as an educational tool for educators, employers, and parents to promote young adults with disabilities as valuable STEM workers. The Forerunners won the Silver Hugo award in the Human Resources category, 2010 International Communications Media competition at the Chicago International Film Festival. It also won the CINE 2011 Golden Eagle award and it was distributed to a large number of stakeholders beyond the target population of this project.
